text: hi everyone Hannah theny Montano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new my
brightest diamond record this is my hand
this is my chin this is my foot this is
my elbow this is my neck this is my knee
this is my review my brightest diamond
is the singer/songwriter project and
band fronted by multi-instrumentalist
Shara Worden with this new LP I believe
she is on her fourth studio album right
now and if you love your vocals
whimsical and theatrical and your pop
songs loaded with dense lavish chamber
and Baroque instrumentation then I
recommend you give her stuff a listen
unquestionably over the year Shara has
done baroque pop and chamber pop quite a
bit of justice though in my opinion
she's never really been like one of the
most bold little artists in the genre
especially in the case of her last
full-length record which I do think had
it's underwhelming moments however on
this new LP of her share is seriously
turning up the heat on numerous tracks
here especially the lead single Shara is
bringing louder instrumentation stronger
percussion and even a few of the quieter
songs on the tracklist here have this
kind of staredown intensity to them that
gives the songs especially the title
track on here a lot of emotional power
plus in addition to being beautifully
orchestrated and arranged and recorded
and mixed really well this album much of
the time is very well written to once
again Shara deliver some great songs on
this record starting with the very
dramatic lead single pressure which
kicks the entire LP off it's a very
dramatic marching band style
instrumentation the dance will groove on
the hook is fantastic there's the
diamonds I didn't know Cher's pop
sensibility could be this great and with
the lyrics on this LP about diamonds and
dispersing light and the pressure
creating these fantastically amazing
stones Sharra's lyrics continue to be
filled with poetry symbolism metaphor
the next track before the words also
feature some
strong drumming I love the backup vocals
on this track beat the drums are
lovingly wrapped in these layers of
vocals this wonderful warm brass it's
gorgeous
instrumentally this song is very refined
but it's visceral as well
this dynamic she hits perfectly on the
song lover killer - it's got lavish
instrumentation like many other tracks
here but the beat behind this thing
wouldn't sound too uncomfortable behind
like a disco track conversely the title
track on this LP is much more toned down
but like I said there's that sort of
quiet emotional intensity to it
especially with the very self-affirming
lyrics and the very slow-growing track
shape is another highlight for me on
here - I love the patient arpeggios I
think the song has these three
individual interesting parts and
especially at the end the song gets
pretty explosive I think the background
vocals on their fantastic
as far as downsides I think there are a
few moments on this LP where maybe Shara
isn't hitting the lyrical mark I've
heard her hit numerous times in the past
like on the track which I sort of hear
the concept of this song but it seems
just like an overly simple portrayal of
the sort of love on the rocks or maybe
tainted or dangerous love situation and
the finish of this LP in my opinion is
not quite as fantastic as the beginning
unfortunately this record doesn't really
stick the the dismount for me and it
starts with tracks like they're easy
which to me this song is just like a
overly long interlude the song resonance
while much more lively feels more like a
groove that goes on and on and on and on
and on than a well formed song and the
closing track on here feels like Shara
just kind of delivering some words or
maybe a poem in your usual vocal style
over a little bit of acoustic and
electronic ambience and while it is very
pretty from an aesthetic standpoint it
is very beautiful texturally I think the
track is a little anticlimactic for a
finisher overall I think this is a
really good record just another decent
LP in the my brightest diamond Canon I
do think it's really worth checking out
there are a few duds in the tracklist
here kind of an
underwhelming finish occasionally the
backing instrumentation feels a little
frivolous or maybe a little bit like
window dressing for kind of a reference
point if you ever heard that band after
clang there's there's definitely
something to the orchestration here that
reminds me of that but for the most part
especially in the first half this is a
very captivating full-length I'm feeling
a decent strong seven on this thing
transition if you've given this LP
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and and
that's it Anthony Fantana
my brightest diamond forever
